member.name: T:System.ServiceModel.Channels.BufferManager
member.summary: Many Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) features require the use of buffers, which are expensive to create and destroy. You can use the class to manage a buffer pool. The pool and its buffers are created when you instantiate this class and destroyed when the buffer pool is reclaimed by garbage collection. Every time you need to use a buffer, you take one from the pool, use it, and return it to the pool when done. This process is much faster than creating and destroying a buffer every time you need to use one.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Creates a new BufferManager with a specified maximum buffer pool size and a maximum size for each individual buffer in the pool.
member.param: The maximum size of the pool.
The maximum size of an individual buffer.
member.exception:
There was insufficient memory to create the requested buffer pool.
Note: In .NET for Windows Store apps or the Portable Class Library, catch the base class exception, , instead.
member.returns: Returns a object with the specified parameters.

member.summary: Returns a buffer to the pool.
member.param: A reference to the buffer being returned.
member.exception: Length of does not match the pool's buffer length property.

member.summary: Gets a buffer of at least the specified size from the pool.
member.param: The size, in bytes, of the requested buffer.
member.returns: A byte array that is the requested size of the buffer.

member.name: T:System.ServiceModel.ConcurrencyMode
member.summary: Specifies whether a service class supports single-threaded or multi-threaded modes of operation.

member.name: F:System.ServiceModel.ConcurrencyMode.Multiple
member.summary: The service instance is multi-threaded. No synchronization guarantees are made. Because other threads can change your service object at any time, you must handle synchronization and state consistency at all times.

member.name: F:System.ServiceModel.ConcurrencyMode.Reentrant
member.summary: The service instance is single-threaded and accepts reentrant calls. The reentrant service accepts calls when you call another service; it is therefore your responsibility to leave your object state consistent before callouts and you must confirm that operation-local data is valid after callouts. Note that the service instance is unlocked only by calling another service over a WCF channel. In this case, the called service can reenter the first service via a callback. If the first service is not reentrant, the sequence of calls results in a deadlock. For details, see .

member.name: F:System.ServiceModel.ConcurrencyMode.Single
member.summary: The service instance is single-threaded and does not accept reentrant calls. If the property is , and additional messages arrive while the instance services a call, these messages must wait until the service is available or until the messages time out.
